title: 104_hr1807
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children's Media Protection Act of 1995". Congress finds that American children are exposed to excessive amounts of television violence, with statistics showing high levels of exposure to murders and other violent acts. Surveys indicate that a majority of Americans believe there is too much violence on television and that it contributes to real-life violence. The media contributes to real-life violence, with studies showing a link between televised violence and increased aggressive behavior in children. Recommendations have been made for producers to exercise greater restraint in programming for children. (8) Parents should have the technology to block inappropriate TV programs for children due to sexual, violent, or indecent content. (9) Technology exists for TV receivers to allow parents to block such programs. Establishment of television rating code. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include rules for identifying and rating inappropriate television programming for children, as well as rules for transmitting signals with ratings. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include rules for identifying and rating inappropriate television programming for children, as well as rules for transmitting signals with ratings that allow viewers to block inappropriate content. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require televisions with screens 13 inches or larger to have circuitry enabling viewers to block channels, programs, and time slots, as well as block all programs with a common rating. This is followed by rules for shipping or importing such televisions. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require televisions with screens 13 inches or larger to have blocking technology. Regulations now prohibit shipping, manufacturing, or importing such televisions without following Commission rules. Carriers transporting these televisions without trading them are exempt. Commission rules must include performance standards for blocking technology. The Communications Act of 1934 amendment mandates that TVs 13 inches or larger must have blocking technology to receive rating signals conforming to Commission specifications. The Commission will ensure blocking service availability as new video technology emerges. Section 330(d) is amended to include additional sections for compliance. SEC. 6. Elimination of television programming inappropriate for children during certain hours. The Children's Television Act of 1990 is amended to include a prohibition on programming unsuitable for children. The Commission must start a rule-making process to ban sexual, violent, and indecent TV programming on commercial television and public telecommunications entities from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Cable operators are included in this prohibition. The term 'public telecommunications entity' is defined in the Communications Act of 1934. SEC. 7. BROADCAST ON TELEVISION AND CABLE OF EDUCATIONAL AND INFORMATIONAL PROGRAMMING FOR CHILDREN. SEC. 7. BROADCAST ON TELEVISION AND CABLE OF EDUCATIONAL AND INFORMATIONAL PROGRAMMING FOR CHILDREN. Section 309 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include conditions for children's television programming on broadcast television, and Part III of title VI is amended to include educational and informational programming requirements for children on cable services. "Franchise awarded under this part must comply with standards for children's TV programming and serve educational needs of children in cable service provision."
